Why it’s good: For a project like this that aims at a single post a day, scheduling posts is a grand idea. The queue is an even better idea however, a list of posts that are automatically published every day at the same time.

I’m about to head off on a weekend trip, so I’ve been queuing up posts to hit for the days that I’m gone. How much do I have in the pipeline? Enough to get through the weekend?

These little tooltips next to each post answer my question immediately. Instead of having to count on my fingers or look at a calendar, I immediatelly know how much buffer I have built up and how long it will last. Perfect!

Day 21 - Neutrogena's Face Wash Ingredients

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

What it is: Neutrogena Naturals Face wash switches up how it handles the ingredients list, showing where the different elements come from.

Why it’s good: The average consumer has an odd relationship with the word “chemical.” We use the term as a stand in for a whole host of other bad terms; toxin, carcinogen, caustic, solvent, cleaner, the list goes on. Chemical names are just as scary, we don’t understand them so we assume it’s bad.

With the natural push in many products, manufacturers have an added difficulty of conveying what the ‘natural’ element of their product is. If I’m uninformed as a consumer, do I have any idea what “Cocamidopropyl Betaine” means? Definitely not, that sounds scary.

By listing where the ingredients come from, Neutrogena gives credibility to its claim. Instead of just seeing a lot of words that I don’t understand, I can see that it comes from a coconut. It’s a move that facilitates confidence, and helps me feel like they aren’t making baseless claims.

Day 20 - Spotify's Improving Station

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When listening to Spotify’s radio, the thumbs up icon tells you that it’s improving the station before adding it to a playlist for you.

Why it’s good: First, the pause is brilliant. I’m sure Spotify doesn’t need any processing time to pick the next song, but this brief pause makes me feel like they’re actually doing something important. The reason that it works to make me wait for a second is that it’s unlikely at this point that I would want to do something else, so the action doesn’t block me.

The part that elevates this to an amazing design is automatically adding it to a playlist. Liking a song to improve a station is a concept that I’m used to because of Pandora. Adding it to a list where I can find it later (and play it by itself) is a direct sell of Spotify’s added value - You can listen to it on the radio, but you can also listen to it by itself. Even though it’s subtle, this interface piece underscores that value proposition.

Day 19 - Google Now's Gas Stations

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When travelling home from Philadelphia this past weekend, I brought up Google Now. It showed me a list of gas stations off of my route, and the amount of time the detour would take.

Why it’s good: It’s been fascinating to watch Google make changes to Now as it’s evolved as a product. When Now first started, it only had the ability to tell you things that were near to you. Useful, sure, but not so much when you’re speeding down an interstate.

This use case is an exact compliment to my needs, it was exactly what my wife and I needed as we travelled down the interstate. The biggest challenge is I don’t know how to make it appear, but Google guessed correctly and made it surface at the right time.

Now I just need it to do the same thing for coffee shops

Day 18 - Starbucks' Case and Tumbler

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Starbucks recently released a line of tumblers in which you can customize the case. The labels on these use alternating color and blind deboss to indicate they are parts of a set.

Why it’s good: It’s hard to indicate to users when they need to pay attention. In software, we have a lot of ways to handle this by locking down the system until certain requirements have been fulfilled. We don’t always have that option though.

This little set is more subtle than slapping big numbers on the tumbler and case, but it provides the same effect. The blind deboss is different, it catches attention enough that you realize that there’s another level of information. Put next to each other, the relationship is clear instantly.

Day 17 - 500px's Terms and Privacy

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

What it is: 500px is a photo sharing and discovery site. Their terms and conditions are a 2 column page, the left column is all the legal-ese required to run a large site, and they then explain it on the right.

Why it’s good: EULA’s and legal text in general are terrible experiences. If each interpersonal relationship began with a 10 minute recitation of what you were agreeing to by entering into this relationship, being a hermit would be much more socially acceptable.

Some products decide to address this by shaming the user into reading the EULA that they’ve agreed to sight unseen. While it makes a product developer feel better, it doesn’t really encourage anyone to enter the situation with more knowledge. 500px takes a different route, it gets that you want to understand what you’re agreeing to, and then gives you the ability to bridge that gap.

The brilliant part of this design is in the juxtaposition. Instead of just writing a long document and then a simplified version, laying it side by side makes me feel as a user that this is an accurate translation. The large copy and short sentences make it easy to scan and understand. It gives me a quicker way to get the same information, which is brilliant.

Day 16 - Bellroy's Product Line

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

Note: This is based on an earlier version of the Bellroy website which you can see at archive.org

What is is: Bellroy is a steadily growing line of “every day carry” items. They began with wallets, which is still the majority of their product line. When they just sold wallets, they arranged their products on a continuum of features, going from “Slimmest” to “Most features.”

Why it’s good: Product lines can be difficult to explain well to an end user. How do you go about showing the difference between the products and helping the user identify the right solution for their needs?

I’ve come back to this particular idea so many times because of how breathtakingly clear it was to me when I was purchasing a wallet from this company. I instantly knew what tradeoffs I was making, and felt like I had a good sense of accomodating my needs. The categorization above the wallets functioned as a breakpoint, helping me determine where exactly my needs lay.

The secondary effect was helping me “fuzzy find” what I wanted. While I wasn’t sure exactly which wallet was right for me, having them displayed in a range like this helped me determine what I didn’t need right off the bat. I spent very little time looking above the “Hide and Seek” or below the “Slim Sleeve” because the range defined where my dividing line was for features that I wanted or needed.

While I was sad to see them iterate away from it, it’s great to see that they didn’t let a great idea hinder the growth of their product line. Clinging to this narrative wouldn’t have made sense when they added phone cases or a more rugged line (The features are different, not just more)

Day 15 - Philadelphia's Tourist Maps

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

What it is: When walking around Philadelphia, there are a number of signs to help orient tourists like me. These signs change based on which direction you’re walking on the street.

Why it’s good: One of the best things about good UX (and in my opinion, one of the things that makes it hardest to talk about) is that the truly best pieces of it are so obvious that they don’t seem worth talking about. When I pointed out these signs to my wife (and pointedly took photos of it,) her comment was “Well of course, how else would you do it?”

The reasons that these signs make so much sense is that they understand their integration with the environment. Not only do they orient you based on the direction you’re walking, they also highlight things that are close and along the route you are walking. Some smaller signs mounted high on lamps take this a step further, recentering the map on you and only showing you the things in front of you.

In all, it’s a tremendously simple effect that has great utility.

Day 14 - Yelp's Map Expansion

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When browsing listings on Yelp, there’s a small map that gives you the location of your different establishments. You can expand the map with a link titled “Mo’ Map” that pops the map open.

Why it’s good: The importance of a map can’t be overstated when looking for something close (in my case, to a hotel). The way that Yelp has handled this walks a delightfully fine line. The playful language makes it feel inconsequential, you aren’t changing your query, just modifying it.

My favorite piece though can be easy to miss, the listings also strip down their complexity when the map is larger. This is done very intentionally to keep the listings approximately the same height, which keeps you at about the same place in the listings if you’ve been browsing them.

Day 13 - Google Drive's Action Bar

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When selecting items in Google Drive, a small toolbar pops up that allows you to star the item, pin it (Which saves it to the device,) share it, or a host of other functions that can be popped up from the side menu.

Why it’s good: Google Drive takes a big risk in the layout of its various files. Because it uses a tile based approach, many of the features that users have come to expect aren’t as readily available in options on the tiles themselves.

Instead of trying to wedge a bunch of icons on the tile itself or taking you to a different screen (Where you wouldn’t have any mass editing options,) this toolbar accurately balances multiple use cases. While it is unfortunate that these icons don’t tell you what they do, the compromise of granular single file activities and mass editing is brilliant.

Day 12 - USAA's Watch Pin

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: USAA recently released an Android Wear update to their app, which lets you see account balance on your watch. The PIN entry system has a large keyboard, and a ring lights up around the watchface to indicate how many digits you’ve entered.

Why it’s good: Interactions on wearable screens are tough because of real estate. The tiny screen and low resolution leaves it difficult to communicate, and the interfaces are highly gestural to combat this.

This interface is a great example of maximizing real-estate and making the experience as painless as possible. The glowing ring is quickly apparent, and shows error state when the pin is incorrect.

Day 11 - Paper's Physical Interface

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: Paper is an application for sketching and diagramming. It uses an extended metaphore of pages and books to navigate and display drawings.

Why it’s good: Tablets are fundamentally different devices than computers. Our input methods, where we use them (usually), our method of engagement, and our emotional state are all different. Consequentially, some of the decades of baggage from designing mouse and keyboard interfaces doesn’t hold up well in touch.

Paper does a wonderful job at relating itself to a different metaphor, books. It brings physicality to this interface to help orient users, and does some pretty heavy handholding when you first begin with it. The little gif above shows how you can move shapes around like a post-it note (including whatever’s drawn on it), and then how pinching motions bring you out of page view and then out of book view. Part of the reason this gestural interface is so successful is because of the requirements of a drawing surface - You don’t want an interface, you want a canvas.

Day 10 - Trello's Board Backgrounds

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: When setting up a new Trello board, you can set a background for it. There’s also a little die that lets you randomize the board background.

Why it’s good: Trello walks a fine line as a brand. On the one hand, they’re playful, silly, and earnest. Their mascot is a Husky named Taco. C'mon. On the other hand, their service is used for everything from home organization (which fits the brand well) to critical business processes (in which the brand could feel pointless and frivolous.) Consequentially, they take a light touch with the sillyness in the actual interface.

Here though, the board backround really isn’t that consequential, and they get that. The randomization function is handled quietly and simply, and with a little zest of fun. It’s a great example of an easter egg that enhances functionality without hindering expert workflows.

Day 9 - Rosenfelds Book's Chapters

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: At the beginning of each chapter, there’s a breakdown of important subheads, a small line diagram, and a full color spread.

Why it’s good: The books that Rosenfeld publishes walk a fine line between reference manual and professional development. These chapter leadins are so successful because they so accurately consider why the consumer is reading this book. The full color spread makes it easy to find these pages as you flip through the book. Detailed headings give an overview of the chapter contents, as well as their locations. My favorite bit is the line graph though, which gives you an example of the relative length of this chapter to the entire book. It’s similar to a Kindle saying “3 hours left in this book,” but more subtle and beautiful.

Day 8 - Android Lollipop's Camera

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: When recording a video with the standard camera in Android Lollipop, holding the phone in portrait mode gives a small icon that prompts you to rotate the phone.

Why it’s good: I’m not the type of person to describe vertical video as a disease of our time, but I’m not exactly the biggest fan of it. In this case, this little reminder seems like a great solution. It doesn’t get in the way, it doesn’t prevent you from recording, and it disappears as soon as you begin recording.

The small reminder is subtle and useful, so hopefully your video isn’t ruthlessly letterboxed on Youtube. Slick.

Day 7 - Toggl's Browser Extension

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: Toggl is a simple, web based, time tracking app. They make a browser extension that places a small button in a variety of different web apps like Trello, Jira, and Gmail. Clicking the button pulls the relevant text from whatever the button is near, and starts a time entry for it.

Why it’s good: There are so many products available. There have been a wave of recent businesses that have made product integrations a central part of their strategy, like Slack or Stripe. Toggl has API integration as well, but it also has this lighter weight browser extension.

The beauty of this extension is that it doesn’t overcomplicate the idea behind timetracking. It gets that you are just trying to start an entry, lets you pick a few options, and then gets out of the way. It also tracks state in both the button and on the favicon, showing me that everything worked correctly. It’s quiet but efficient.

Day 6 - YNAB's Entry Screen

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: YNAB is a budgeting app (Short for You Need a Budget (You probably do)). It is a powerful example of a UI being shaped by underlying philosophy. Back to the point - When you are entering income, if you indicate something is income and then enter the dollars in as an outflow, it stops you with a modal window.

Why it’s good: Modal windows are awful. This is especially true in an interface like this, where I’m using all keyboard entry and have to find my mouse.

This modal is necessary though, and it is a gold standard for best practices. It appears at a reasonable time, after I’ve finished typing and hit enter or clicked save. It has very short, scannable copy that includes bold text to help me figure out the issue. It uses semantically accurate copy on the buttons, indicating what each does. It even has a somewhat self deprecating header “Hey user, I’m being rude, just let me check this really quick.”

It is rude, but it’s saved me more than one headache as I speed through entering transactions and so I’m grateful for it.

Day 5 - Marshall's Dressing Rooms

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: In the dressing room at Marshalls (A discount clothing retailer) the hooks on the walls for hangers are labeled with small signs reading “Definitely,” “Possibly,” and “Tomorrow”

Why it’s good: Trying on clothes is not an incredibly fun experience, so anything that makes me more comfortable is welcome. In one corner, “Definitely” and “Possibly” are right next to each other, allowing for quick comparisons. “Tomorrow,” while not being incredibly well labelled, is across the room, giving some separation. With a few simple signs (and some great natural feeling light), Marshalls subtlety directs the entire experience.

Day 4 - Pocket's Clipboard

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What is is: Pocket is an app that helps you keep track of things you want to read. On iOS, when you open the app while you have a URL on your clipboard, Pocket asks if you would like to save it.

Why it’s good: One of the more frustrating behaviors on iOS is the limited way that apps are allowed to talk to each other. If your data cannot be pushed through the native share functionality, there’s no way to get information between apps, right?

What’s so lovely about this small, unobtrusive interaction is that Pocket realizes that you cannot always share a url that you want to save, sometimes it comes up in a weird place that doesn’t allow you that flexibility. This little interaction doesn’t get in your way, but it does realize that if you have a URL that you’ve copied, you probably want to do something with it.

Day 3 - Kickstarter's Newsletter

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: Kickstarter newsletter sign up in the footer of their site. Clicking the scissors three times causes the footer to fall off and the sign up form to appear in its place.

Why it’s good: I have a special dislike for mailing list signups, largely because so many sites seem to bludgeon me over the head with them. Kickstarter’s newsletter signup sets a completely different tone for what they’re accomplishing, you aren’t just opting to recieve emails, you’re joining the club.

This is a true example of delightful design; The designers didn’t just craft a goofy animation, it’s a genuinely suprising effect. It is a perfect support to Kickstarter’s playful, small company image, quite a feat considering their size and revenue.

Day 2 - Beam Telepresence

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: A mobile robot, about 5'7" tall and remotely controlled. The user has an interface that allows them to drive the robot around and it has 2 way voice and visual communication.

Why it’s good: The woman pictured here is Kavita Krishnaswami - a PHD student in Computer Science at UMBC. Kavita’s physical disabilities render her bedridden, so she attends conferences and gives talks with the Beam Telepresence.

I met her this past Wednesday at her presentation on robotics and disability. She came up to me, we introduced ourselves, spoke for a bit, and then broke off the conversation naturally. I had a thrill when I realized the agency that this machine provided her that cannot be matched by a Skype call, or even a wheelchair.

The makers of this product have put a lot of time into making it feel natural and considering who will use it and how. The height of the screen and camera are at about average eye level. The robot is quick, but not so much so that it’s unstable or disconcerting. There are small details too, like lights illuminating the support pillars, making it so the robot isn’t just a floating screen in dark environments.

At one point in her presentation, Kavita described the first time using a beam, saying “It was the first time I had ever stood.” This product is clearly informed by a deep understanding of the motivations and needs of its users, and that is instantly apparent when you see it in use.

Day 1 - Tumblr's Dashboard

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: This is the second step after I create my account, after skipping the “follow these blogs” step. Suggested content appears all around, but this is clearly the center of the interface.

Why it’s good: The animation is subtle, but friendly. It draws me to the center of the screen, uses casual and accessible language, and indicates interactivity. The dashed lines act as a wireframe to indicate how content will come in if I follow blogs, avatar and posts. There are also more subtle things going on, like introducing you to the unique icon that Tumblr uses for “Link.”

This ends up for a great launch point to start my blog. It doesn’t feel like a huge deal, it feels natural, easy, and directed.
